MAIN ESTIMATES, 1962 (Cont.)


    Head 48 -

    The Chairman: The Question is,

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of subhead 1."

    I understood there is going to be a debate on the People's Association in respect of this item.

Column: 1946



    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, if a civil servant makes a declaration which is of a political character, then he is not acting properly as a civil servant. The Director of Social Welfare has done this. We know the Department of Social Welfare is a department which has to shoulder many responsibilities, including assistance to needy people. Therefore, if the Director of Social Welfare makes statements of a political nature, they tend to confuse the people and cause misunderstanding.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I explained last evening that the Director of Social Welfare was appointed Secretary and Treasurer of the People's Association under the People's Association Ordinance. Since community centres are one of the social services provided by the Social Welfare Department, therefore the Director of Social Welfare was appointed to serve the People's Association.

    With regard to the allegation that he is being asked to issue public statements of a political nature, as I explained last evening, he is purely an employee and he carries out the instructions of the Board. Whatever statement that is issued through him is the opinion and policy of the Board.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Pasir Panjang can hardly expect to get away with the statement that civil servants are being used as political instruments of a political Party. All the published statements that this officer has made related to acts of hooliganism and violence indulged in by the former employees of the People's Association. I see nothing political in them. He was just stating that they went round centres, breaking windows and inciting children to damage property. Where is the political line? If the Member for Pasir Panjang says that the officer is engaged in a political light against the Barisan Sosialis and this assumption is implicit in his statement it just proves what we have been saying, that the Barisan Sosialis are supporting the former employees of the People's Association.

Column: 1947



    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to put it to a vote.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    The Chairman: Mrs Seow Peck Leng, amendment (1) on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to seek your guidance on this. Could I take amendments (1) to (21)* as a whole first, as there are three questions I would like to ask, which I shall have to repeat 20 times if I do not take them together? After I have done that, I will pick out a few and speak on them. Can I do that?
*Amendments (1) to (21) read as follows:

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of items (23) to (43) of subhead 1.


    The Chairman: Yes, certainly. First, move the first amendment.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Thank you. I beg to move,

    That the sum to he allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (23) of subhead 1.

    Sir, the three questions that I said I intended to ask on the posts shown in items (23) to (43) are - how many of these posts, except the new post that is to be filled in 1962, are vacant; how long have they been vacant; and why have they been kept vacant?

    The Chairman: I suppose the hon. Member should pose all her three questions.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Yes, Mr Speaker. The three questions are - how many of them are vacant; how long have they been vacant; and the reason why they have been kept vacant?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have only this morning obtained a list of the personnel in the Department of Social Welfare and this was complied as at 1st January, 1961.

    According to this list, we have only one vacant post of Aftercare Officer, two posts of Assistant Lady Superintendent,

Column: 1948

one post of Assistant Warden, two posts of Cook, two posts of Welfare Attendant. The two vacant posts of Cook are in Grade II. These are all the vacancies I find on this list.

    As to when they have been vacant, as I said, this list was complied as at 1st January, 1961, and I do not know the dates when these posts were vacant, but I am sure the Director of Social Welfare must have taken action to fill these posts.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I just saw the day before yesterday in the programme of the exhibition next door that the two posts of Assistant Superintendent have been filled, but I do not know about the others. Why I ask whether there are vacancies is that I know there has been a clamour for more staff; the homes are inefficiently run not because of the inefficiency of the staff, but because of the lack of staff. Since we have the vote, I do not quite know why those posts have been kept vacant. What I would like to know is whether it is difficult to get qualified people. Or what is the reason for keeping such posts vacant?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I remember sometime last year I enquired from the Director of Social Welfare whether he had taken steps to fill all the vacant posts in the Social Welfare Department. He told me he had referred this question to the Establishment. It seems the Establishment Branch held up the establishment because they anticipated a batch of graduates from the Social Science Faculty of the University of Malaya. I do not know whether the posts have been advertised by now.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I hope that that is an assurance that in 1962 the vacant posts will be filled. Thank you.

    Now on item (24), I wonder why one person is getting $565 up to a maximum of $685.

Column: 1949



    The Chairman: Order. If the hon. Member has finished on general principles covering the whole of the Residential Institutions, perhaps I could now go amendment by amendment. Are there any matters of general principle? No? I will put the Question on the first amendment if the Member for Mountbatten wants a vote on it. The first amendment is on the three Superintendents.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, that will not be my first amendment. My first amendment will be on item (24). I have covered item (23).

2.45 p.m.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (24) of subhead 1.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, item (24) shows "2 Lady Superintendents", one drawing $565-685 and the other (Salary Code II-24) drawing $595-675. So while the latter starts with a higher salary, she ends with a lower salary. And the former, while starting with a lower salary, ends with a higher salary, and that is supposed to be a personal scale. I wonder whether there is any special reason why a personal scale, separate from the timescale, is given to her.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The answer is quite simple, Mr Speaker, Sir. Every now and then salary scales are revised because of abnormal rates in comparison with other scales. And quite often salary scales are reduced or altered to the advantage of the present holder. When such a thing happens, the present holder

Column: 1950

can opt to remain on the more advantageous salary scale while new recruits will he brought in at the revised salary scale.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: In view of the explanation, may I have your permission to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (25) of subhead 1.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 2 Assistant Superintendents against this item. In view of the fact that more Assistant Superintendents are asked for in the Junior Approved School when it comes up, could the Minister tell us whether the two Assistant Superintendents would be sent there or would they remain where they are now?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, this matter will be looked into by the Director of Social Welfare. No doubt when the time comes he will make recommendations, and we will see that there is justification for the transfer or recruitment of additional staff. Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not trying to be impertinent, but the Member for Mount-batten is a member of the Board of Visitors and I am sure all these things could be clarified by the Board.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: That is exactly why I am asking this. I notice there is a grant for the building of the Junior Approved School in the Development Estimates. But I do not see anywhere else a vote for its staff. I am just wondering whether these people will be taken out to fill the posts there, or whether the Government intends to put in Supplementary Estimates later on. I see no Estimates at all for the staff of the school that is coming up.

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is typical of the hon. Lady. She comes to see me in my office and tells me there are dirty drains along Haig Road. I send the Cleansing Department men there to get them cleansed. And she comes into

Column: 1951

this Assembly and asks me to make a report to the Assembly on the dirty drains.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Mountbatten is a member of the Advisory Committee on institutions which are run by the Social Welfare Board. When I was in the Ministry, Mr Speaker, Sir, I chaired a meeting every month and all members of the Committee were present at the meetings. It was their duty to break themselves up into sections, one section visiting regularly the Boys' Home, another the Girls' Home, and another the Mount Emily Home, and one section visited the Homes for the Aged Persons, at Woodstock and at Bushey Park. All the information gathered, Mr Speaker, Sir, was regularly discussed at our meetings. The hon. Member used to attend these meetings very irregularly. To make a show of it, she comes to this Assembly and asks me questions the answers to which would have been available to her had she attended the meetings regularly.

    As far as the Junior Approved School is concerned, Mr Speaker, Sir, she would know, if she had attended the meetings, that we have brought a Mr Riley out, a U.N. consultant, to advise us on the site for the school and the type of building required. One proposal is to convert the Buona Vista Community Centre into an approved school. As soon as we get a report from him, Mr Speaker, Sir, plans will have to be put in for the building of the school, and we would also have to enter provisions for instructors posts for this Junior Approved School. The experience required for the running of the Junior Approved School is entirely different from that required of the Assistant Superintendents who are running the Orphanage at the Perak Home for boys, and the Assistant Superintendents at the Gimson School.

    I hope I have now explained the position to the satisfaction of the Member for Mountbatten.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, for the Minister's information, the drains he mentioned are still in the same

Column: 1952

condition as they were. I shall be bringing up this matter again and again until the drains are cleaned. I went round there yesterday - I will not go into details - and I saw what I saw last Wednesday.

    It is typical of the Minister to avoid the issue. I know Mr Riley has sent in a report asking for one Supervisor, one Assistant Supervisor, and 3 House-masters. I will not go into the details of this list of officers. I see there is no increase in the staffing except in one or two cases. And that is why I ask: what is to happen to the recommendations by the expert from the United Nations, Mr Riley? Is Government going to supply all the staff; or does Government think that he is asking too much; or is Government going to decide later what he is going to have? I have seen the vote already. Knowing that it is a conversion of a building and not a new building, I except it to be finished by next year. Had it been a new building, I would not have asked but would have taken it for granted that the building would not be ready by next year. But knowing that it is a conversion of the Buona Vista Community Centre, I expect it to be ready. If it could not be ready, all that Government need say is, "It will not be ready and so we will not need the staff." It is a simple question.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a saying, "Don't count your chickens before they are hatched." When the building comes up, all we have to do is to put in an A.S.V. for the extra funds required.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, no wonder the Government are in chaos. They do not plan ahead. Anyway, Mr Speaker, in view of the explanation given, I beg to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not moving my amendments to items (26), (27), (28), and (29), but I shall be moving my amendment to item (30).

Column: 1953



    The Chairman: The Member is not moving amendments (4), (5), (6) and (7), but will move amendment (8), i.e., in respect of item (30)?
The amendments read as follows:

    (4) That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (26) of subhead 1.

    (5) That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (27) of subhead 1.

    (6) That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (28) of subhead 1.

    (7) That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (29) of subhead 1.


    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Yes.

    The Chairman: Please move.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (30) of subhead 1.

    Sir, item (30) says, "1 Child Care Officer". There is in existence a boarding-out scheme for babies, and it has long been requested that Government supplies a Child Care Officer. There is another request from the expert from the United Nations, I believe it is for the boarding-out scheme for Perak House. He thinks that is overcrowded and that a boarding-out scheme should be started. And for that, he has also, in his report, asked for one Child Care Officer. Now, could the Minister or his Parliamentary Secretary tell us whether this Child Care Officer is to be for the babies or for the new project that has been recommended? I just want to know whether the new project is to come up and whether this Child Care Officer is for that project.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, from our experience we have found that it is much more beneficial for the child if it is hoarded out with a family who agrees to look after the child. Also it is much cheaper if such arrangements are made. Mr Speaker, Sir, we did have a Child Care Officer for babies sometime ago, but for some reason or other that appointment was abolished. Now, the intention is to introduce a new post of Child Care Officer so that this officer will be in charge not only of babies but of children up to the age of, say, 10 years, so that he will be able to look after and supervise proper and suitable boarding-out

Column: 1954

schemes for the young boys at Perak Home and for the young girls at the Girls' Homecraft Centre.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sir, I do not know whether I interpret this correctly. Do I take it that the Minister means that this officer will do the job connected with the old project as well as the project that is existing, as well as starting a boarding-out scheme for Perak House? Of course, it is only a recommendation and has not come into existence yet.

    Mr Byrne: That is so, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether the Minister means that one officer will be sufficient. I would like to draw his attention to it, and I hope he will look into it and see whether one officer is sufficient - he is the authority on the subject. With that, I would like to withdraw, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the observations made by the Member for Mountbatten will no doubt be looked into.

    The Chairman: It is at this stage that the Member asks leave to withdraw.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: I beg to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The following amendment stood in the name of Mrs Seow Peck Leng -

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (31) of subhead 1.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: I am not moving my amendment to item (31), Mr Speaker. Sir. My next amendment is to item (32).

    The Chairman: Yes.

Column: 1955



    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (32) of subhead 1.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this item shows "1 Lady Warden", which is a new appointment. The note says, "For Girls' Hostel". As far as my knowledge goes, I think I am correct in saying that the Girls' Hostel has one Lady Warden now, who has been drawn from the Yorkhill Home, what they call the Girls' Homecraft Centre. I am just wondering, Sir, when this new Lady Warden is appointed, will the Lady Warden from the Girls' Hostel go back to Yorkhill and this new Lady Warden will take over her job in the Girls' Hostel? Or will the same person be allowed to remain and the new appointee goes to Yorkhill? I feel very strongly that this Lady Warden who has been posted from Yorkhill to the Girls' Hostel is doing the job most efficiently, and having done it for a few months, I feel it is wiser that she be kept there to continue her work so that there will be a continuation of work, and for obvious reasons it is better to keep her there.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Byrne: We had provision from the previous estimates for the building of a Girls' Hostel. We also have funds from C. D. & W, for that purpose. We have found' the girls temporary accommodation in an old Government building in Canning Rise. The Ministry of Finance wants this building for the housing of overseas officers. We shall have to look for an old building and convert it for this purpose, or use C. D. & W, funds to build a new Girls' Hostel, in any case, Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Member for Mountbatten has rightly pointed out, to start off this hostel we have to transfer somebody from the Girls' Homecraft Centre to this hostel. These jobs are filled through the Public Service Commission. They will have to be advertised. There will be other people also who will be applying. It will be up to the Public Service Commission to make the selection. We cannot give any assurance to the Member for Mountbatten that, because she considers this lady who is acting in this appointment to be suitable, that would also be the view of the Public Service Commission.

Column: 1956



    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sir, in view of the explanation, I beg to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The following amendments stood in the name of Mrs Seow Peck Leng -

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (33) of subhead 1.*

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (34) of subhead 1.+

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (35) of subhead 1.++

    The Chairman: Amendment (11) .

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (36) of subhead 1.

    Sir, item (36) shows there will be one extra instructor. There are already 23. May I ask, Sir, what qualifications are required for this extra instructor? I am a bit doubtful because I see here the sum of $90,130 as against $84,000, which is an increase of $5,870. If the instructor is to be appointed on the same salary scale as the existing instructors, which is $220 a month to start with, there is an excess of $3,230, is this instructor a special instructor who is going to be paid on a higher scale, or is the $3,230 just the normal increments for the existing 23 instructors? It might very well be. But I just want to know whether it is a special instructor who is going to be appointed, at a special salary scale since the amount is so different.

    Mr Byrne: The salary codes are indicated here, Mr Speaker, Sir - one for men instructors and one for women instructors. There is nothing special. This instructor will not be given any special salary. If it is a woman instructor, she will get a salary within the salary code of III 41, and if it is a man instructor, his salary will be within the salary code of III 22.

Column: 1957



    The Chairman: It looks as though it will be a woman instructor. It is for the Mt. Emily Girls' Home.

    Mr Byrne: It will be so.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Then I take it, Sir, that the $3,230 increase is just for annual increments of the other 23 instructors. In view of that explanation, I beg to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (37) of subhead 1.

    Sir, item (37) says "Projects Supervisor". I was just comparing item (36) with item (37), and thinking that they were having a special instructor for item (36), I was wondering a projects supervisor does not need a man who is better qualified than an ordinary instructor. You will notice, Sir, he is on the same pay scale as the instructors. I feel that since the man has to organise projects, the Government might need a more efficient or better qualified man on a better salary scale for the sake of the efficiency of the job that this supervisor is going to undertake.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, some of the boys remain in the hostels for a period of about six to nine months. The system of organisation there is quite unlike the system of organisation in the homes like the Gimson School, where the boys are placed in the custody of the home for three years, and where courses of instruction and training can be organised for the boys. In the case of the Bukit Batok Hostel and other hostels for boys, Mr Speaker, the boys are there for short periods. It would be the duty of this projects instructor to organise worthwhile projects for them, projects that they can begin and complete within the short time that they are living in these hostels. It is for this purpose that, on the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, of which the Member for Mount-batten is a member, this provision has been entered in the Estimates.

Column: 1958



    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, I thank the Minister for that information. I realise this is what the Board has recommended, but we have not stated the qualifications of the instructor. I was just pointing out to the Minister, in case it is an oversight, that this is a more important job and whether it would not need a better qualified man. But the matter is in his hands. Because of my interest in social work and because of my desire to see that the homes function as efficiently as they can, I am bringing these points to his notice from the experience that I have had in my social work. In view of the explanation, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 48 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (38) of subhead 1.

    This is the "Assistant Housemistress". I notice that the salary scale is III 77. which means that she draws a salary of $122 to a maximum of $270. I was just wondering what her duties are for $122. An ordinary domestic amah gets that. If her duties are no more than an ordinary amah - but in a glorified term, she is called "Assistant Housemistress", I am quite satisfied. But in case she is really to assist the Housemistress in doing some sort of organising work, I feel that that salary scale will not get the type of person we want.

    The Chairman: The scale is from $122 to $270, is it?

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Yes.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, this really proves that the Member for Mountbatten has not been doing her homework. The provision for this post was entered in the Estimates for the Woodstock Home. That is the home for old ladies, Mr Speaker, Sir. As the Member for Mountbatten knows, when we started this home we had a male officer who was, seconded from one of the institutions to this home to look after the old ladies. The subcommittee in charge of this home has repeatedly made representations to the committee that it is not fair to keep this man, a single male, amongst the old

Column: 1959

ladies. They consider we should introduce this new post so that a lady house-mistress can be employed to assist him in caring for the old ladies. That is the position. If the Member for Mountbatten had really done her homework, she would have known all about this post.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is typical of the Minister. A straightforward question does not get a straightforward answer. I know all this. He is telling me nothing new. We did recommend a female to be there. But all I ask is, is this female going to share the work of the male, whatever the officer in charge there is called, or is she just going to do more or less the work of an amah? I feel a salary of $122 is not sufficient if we want an Assistant House-mistress of calibre who can really work with the housemaster, if he is known there as such. Anyway, in view of the difficulty the Minister has in answering that question, I will not cause a delay, Sir. I beg leave to withdraw.

    The Chairman: Order. If the hon. Member begs leave to withdraw, she should not preface the request by a long speech. That might indicate she does want an answer. The Minister is perfectly entitled to answer if he wishes to answer. There is no dissentient voice anyway.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
